We examine the relationship between two distinct approaches for constructing the mirror partner of a Calabi-Yau orbifold. We introduce a novel mixed-variable symplectic (MVS) integrator designed for planetary systems, capable of accurately resolving close encounters. Entanglement serves as a fundamental resource in quantum information science. In the framework of general relativity, the Kerr spacetime stands as the sole stationary solution describing an isolated black hole, characterized by a distinctive multipolar structure determined exclusively by its mass and angular momentum. Unlike the Kerr metric, these solutions may violate both axial and equatorial symmetries, exhibiting a far more intricate multipolar structure that offers a phenomenological window into constraining fuzzball models. Our numerical analysis reveals a consistent trend: all multipole moments in these geometries generally exceed (in absolute magnitude) their Kerr black hole counterparts with equivalent mass and spin parameters. While present observational constraints on black-hole candidates' quadrupole moments impose only modest limitations on fuzzball scenarios, forthcoming gravitational-wave observations from LISA's extreme mass-ratio inspirals are projected to enhance these constraints by several orders of magnitude.

Analyzing dynamic graphs that evolve through time presents significant challenges across diverse fields including bioinformatics, physics, and social network analysis. To address these limitations, we introduce an innovative framework combining temporal point processes with variational autoencoders. We present experimental observations of thermally induced transverse vibrations in a photonic crystal waveguide (PCW) structure. We demonstrate canonical decompositions for the evaluations of global Mackey functors on orthogonal, unitary, and symplectic groups. The pursuit of causal understanding through observational data lies at the heart of research in health and social sciences. The Weak Gravity Conjecture (WGC) posits that any viable quantum theory of gravity must incorporate superextremal particles. The quest to unravel how strongly correlated two-dimensional systems can produce unconventional superconductivity with elevated critical temperatures remains a pivotal challenge in condensed matter physics. When random effects correlate with survey design variables, conventional methodsâ€”which use individual sampling weights (calculated as inverses of inclusion probabilities) to create pseudo-likelihoodsâ€”fail to deliver asymptotically unbiased results. Deep hashing techniques have demonstrated exceptional performance in large-scale image retrieval systems, achieving remarkable accuracy while maintaining computational efficiency. Our research explores the phenomenology of a hypercharge-zero SU(2) triplet scalar field, which arises naturally in models featuring a two-stage electroweak symmetry-breaking mechanism. We analyze two distinct scenarios: one where these triplet scalars remain stable and potentially constitute a component of dark matter, and another where they decay through interactions with the Standard Model Higgs boson.  

In the stable triplet scenario, stringent constraints emerge from LHC searches for disappearing charged tracks and from direct dark matter detection experiments.
